CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Protection of property (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 1 - Deprivation of property;Possessions)
JUDGES: André Potocki;Angelika Nußberger;Carlo Ranzoni;Erik Møse;Síofra O’Leary;Yonko Grozev
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

CARDINAL . The applicant had ownership rights to a shop at FAC in PERSON . According to the certificate “ on the sale of ORG property to legal entities or individuals ” issued on DATE by ORG , the total area of the property was QUANTITY . m and it had been purchased by the applicant from the ORG for CARDINAL old NORP manats ( NORP ) ( equivalent to CARDINAL NORP manats ( ORG ) or MONEY ) .

CARDINAL . According to the property ’s “ technical passport ” issued by ORG on DATE , the shop had originally been constructed in DATE , was located on a plot of land of QUANTITY m , had a total surface area of QUANTITY m and was QUANTITY . The shop had concrete foundations , the external and internal walls were made of metal and wood , while the roof was made of metal and covered with slate tiles . The property was classified as a nonresidential building used for wholesale or retail trade purposes . The document further stated that the plot of land on which the shop was located had been allocated on the basis of relevant documents . No other documents concerning the ownership of the land have been submitted by the parties .
CARDINAL . The applicant paid land tax for DATE of NORP CARDINAL,CARDINAL for the plot underneath the shop .

CARDINAL . In DATE the Ganja City Executive Authority ( “ the LOC ” ) decided to renovate and widen Attarlar and Nizami Streets in accordance with the city ’s planning scheme because the streets were not wide enough for the pedestrian and car traffic .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , in DATE ORG officials asked him verbally to vacate the shop in connection with the above decision . The applicant refused and brought a legal action asking the court to order the ORG to stop its allegedly unlawful activities .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , in DATE the ORG destroyed the shop . According to the Government , the shop , being a transportable metal construction , was lifted away by crane and moved to an unspecified part of the city .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE the applicant asked PERSON , a private valuation firm , to assess the shop ’s market value . According to ORG expert report , dated DATE , the market value at the time was AZM CARDINAL , or MONEY ( ORG ) ( there is no copy of the report in the case file ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant supplemented his court action against the ORG with additional claims , asking for compensation of ORG CARDINAL for the shop , ORG for an unspecified “ ORG fee ” and NORP for ORG fee for the report .

CARDINAL . In its submissions to the court , the ORG as the respondent stated that a number of “ old shops and other retail facilities ” on Attarlar and Nizami Streets had been removed owing to the urgent need to widen the streets in order to accommodate the number of pedestrians and cars . The respondent argued that the applicant ’s shop had not been destroyed but , being a metal construction , had been removed by crane to another , unspecified location in the city . The applicant had been offered another plot of land in the city to continue operating his shop but he had refused . The applicant had not owned the original plot of land . The respondent argued that the compensation claimed by the applicant was excessive , taking into account the price he had paid the ORG for it in DATE .
CARDINAL . Following the respondent ’s submissions concerning the alleged excessiveness of the compensation claim , by an interim decision of DATE the ORG requested a new valuation by a ORG expert .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the ORG expert refused to issue an opinion , noting that the shop at CARDINAL FAC no longer existed and that therefore it was technically impossible to examine it and assess its market value . Accordingly , the interim decision of DATE remained unexecuted .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s legal action without citing any provisions of the applicable domestic law . In its reasoning the court accepted the ORG ’s explanation that the shop in question had been removed in accordance with townplanning policy . Being a metal construction it had been possible to move it in one piece . It had not been destroyed but simply transported to another location . The court also accepted that the applicant had been offered a new plot of land by the ORG but had refused it . It further decided to reject the applicant ’s compensation claim based on ORG report , without providing any reasons . However , the court ordered the ORG to allocate the applicant a plot of land in PERSON equivalent in size to the shop in question .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , reiterating that his shop had been unlawfully destroyed and asking for compensation .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal , upholding the first - instance court ’s assessment . The appellate judgment contained no references to applicable domestic legal provisions .
CARDINAL . Following a further appeal by the applicant , on DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment .
CARDINAL . No information is available in the case file as to whether a new land plot was allocated to the applicant or as to its location or any other details .
